questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presented with sudden painless loss of vision and the following finding on fundoscopy. The artery involved is a direct branch of the vessel that travels through which of the following?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of sudden painless loss of vision with a cherry red spot noted on fundoscopy is suggestive of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). The central retinal artery is a direct branch of the ophthalmic artery which passes through the optic canal.

The structures passing through the optic canal are the optic nerve and the ophthalmic artery.

The major structures passing through the superior orbital fissure (Option A) are:

  • Oculomotor, Trochlear and Abducens Nerves (CN III, IV, VI)
  • Lacrimal, Frontal and Nasociliary branches of the ophthalmic division of the Trigeminal Nerve (CN V1)
  • Superior and Inferior Ophthalmic Veins

The structures passing through the inferior orbital fissure (Option B) are:

  • Infraorbital and Zygomatic branches of the maxillary division of the Trigeminal Nerve (CN V2)

The structures passing through the cavernous sinus (Option C) are:

  • Internal Carotid Artery
  • Abducens Nerve

The structures in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus are:

  • Oculomotor, Trochlear and Ophthalmic Division of the Trigeminal Nerves (CN III, IV, V1)

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

questions.text: A young female patient from a rural area presented with severe pain in the lower abdomen and pelvic regions and vaginal bleeding. Her last menstrual period was 2 months back. Her urine pregnancy test appeared positive. Her physician suspected a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. However, no medical imaging or laboratory procedure was available.  The physician could confirm the diagnosis by obtaining the blood from?
questions.solution:
The physician could confirm the diagnosis by obtaining the blood from the rectouterine pouch, which is also called the pouch of Douglas. This procedure is called culdocentesis.

The classic triad of symptoms in tubal pregnancy are

  • Severe lower abdominal pain
  • Amenorrhea- usually for 6-8 weeks before the appearance of the symptoms
  • Vaginal bleeding

If a ruptured ectopic pregnancy is suspected, then blood samples should be sent for haemoglobin estimation and blood grouping. Estimation of β-HCG can be used to confirm pregnancy. Once it is suspected, transvaginal sonography or laparoscopy can be performed to visualise the ruptured ectopic.

However, if the imaging techniques are not available, then culdocentesis can be performed. An 18 gauge lumbar puncture needle with a syringe is inserted into the rectouterine pouch by puncturing the posterior fornix. If non-clotting blood is obtained from the pouch, which has a hematocrit of more than 15%, it indicates the presence of ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

Peritoneum of the female pelvis:

In females, the peritoneum covers the anterior and anterolateral surface of the rectum, uterus, and urinary bladder. Spaces found in the female pelvis are:

  • Pararectal fossae- Present on either side of the rectum. They are limited laterally by the peritoneum that covers the uterosacral ligaments. 
  • Paravesical fossae- Present on either side of the bladder. It is limited laterally by the peritoneum, which covers the round ligament of the uterus.
  • Rectouterine pouch (pouch of Douglas)- The peritoneum, which covers the anterior surface of the rectum, is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterior surface of the posterior fornix of the vagina and the uterus, forming a rectouterine pouch.
  • Vesicouterine pouch- The peritoneum covering the fundus and body of the uterus is reflected anteriorly to cover the posterosuperior surface of the bladder, forming a vesicouterine pouch.
  • Ovarian fossa- a shallow depression in the peritoneal lining of the lateral pelvic wall between the peritoneal ridges. It is formed by the obliterated umbilical arteries anteriorly, the ureter posteriorly, and the external iliac vessels above. It lies behind the lateral attachment of the broad ligament and contains the ovary in nulliparous females.

questions.text: During radical neck dissection in a case of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the oropharynx, the oncosurgeon points out the given structure. Which of the following muscles is not supplied by it?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the ansa cervicalis. The geniohyoid is innervated by the first cervical spinal nerve and not ansa cervicalis. 

Ansa cervicalis is a loop of nerves that are a part of the cervical plexus. It is made up of two roots. The upper root has contributions from the first cervical spinal nerve, and the lower root has contributions from the second and third cervical spinal nerves. It innervates the sternohyoid, sternothyroid, and omohyoid muscles.

Thyrohyoid and geniohyoid are not supplied by ansa cervicalis. They are supplied by branches of the first cervical spinal nerve via the hypoglossal nerve.

questions.text: A young adolescent male with a recurrent history of suppurative otitis media was brought to the hospital with high fever and chills, altered sensorium, and neck rigidity. Which part of the image given below should have been deficient for the patient to develop the current symptoms?
questions.solution:
The tegmen tympani (Marked as 2 in the image), which forms the roof of the middle ear cavity, should have been deficient for the patient to develop meningitis from suppurative otitis media.

Tegmen tympani separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa. It also extends posteriorly to form the roof of the aditus and antrum as tegmen mastoidea. Any deficit in the tegmen tympani can facilitate the spread of middle ear infection to the middle cranial fossa.

The middle ear has a roof, floor, and four walls: anterior, posterior, medial & lateral.

  • Roof: Formed by tegmen tympani bone
  • Floor: Formed by a thin plate of bone
  • Anterior wall: Structures related are
    • Eustachian tube (option C)
    • Canal of tensor tympani (option D)
    • Internal carotid artery
  • Posterior wall (option A): It has a bony projection called a pyramid. The aditus connecting the middle ear to the attic is above the pyramid. The posterior sinus, also known as the facial recess, is a depression in the posterior wall lateral to the pyramid. It is bounded medially by the vertical part of the facial nerve (VIIth nerve), laterally by the chorda tympani, and above, by the fossa incudis. Intact canal wall techniques use this for middle ear access.
  • Medial wall: It is formed by a labyrinth, and it presents as a bulge called promontory. The medial wall is related to:
    • Oval window
    • Round window
    • Processus cochleoriformis
    • Horizontal semicircular canal
    • Canal of the facial nerve
  • Lateral wall: It is mainly formed by the tympanic membrane and also by the bony outer attic wall called scutum.

questions.text: A 55-year-old chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with early-stage hepatocellular carcinoma in the right lobe and is scheduled for a right anterior sectionectomy. Which of the following segments have to be removed in the patient?
questions.solution:
In the right anterior sectionectomy, segments V and VIII are removed. 

Cantlie’s line or main portal fissure extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava. It divides the liver into the right and left hemiliver. It contains the middle hepatic vein. The liver has 3 major fissures and 3 minor fissures.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage. The left lobe is composed of the left lateral segment (Couinaud’s segments II and III) and the left medial segment (segment IV). The right lobe is composed of segments V, VI, VII, and VIII, with segments V and VIII making up the right anterior lobe and segments VI and VII making up the right posterior lobe.

Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Segments removed in various liver surgeries:

  • Right hepatectomy or right Hemi-hepatectomy - V, VI, VII, VIII 
  • Right tri-sectionectomy or extended right hepatectomy - IV, V, VI, VII, VIII 
  • Right anterior sectionectomy- V, VIII 
  • Right posterior sectionectomy - VI, VII 
  • Left hepatectomy or left hemi-hepatectomy - II, III, and IV
  • Left tri-sectionectomy or extended left hepatectomy - II, III, IV, V, and VIII
  • Left medial sectionectomy- IV

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: A child is brought with complaints of bitemporal hemianopia, severe headaches associated with vomiting, growth failure, and delayed sexual maturation. CT scan showed the presence of a tumor with calcifications. T1 weighed MRI of the brain is done and is shown below. What is the embryonal basis for this tumor?
questions.solution:
The child has a craniopharyngioma derived from the Rathke pouch, which may persist in the roof of the nasopharynx as a pharyngeal hypophysis.

Rathke’s pouch appears as an evagination of the oral cavity at about 3 weeks of embryonic life. It grows dorsally towards the infundibulum and eventually loses its connection to the oral cavity by the end of the 8th week. The anterior wall cells multiply rapidly to form the anterior pituitary or adenohypophysis, and the posterior wall of the pouch forms pars intermedia. The anterior wall cells have a small extension that grows along the stalk of the infundibulum, forming pars tuberalis.

Craniopharyngiomas are benign masses usually present in the suprasellar or intrasellar regions. They arise near the pituitary stalk and can produce functional impairment of the hypophysis due to the mass effect. They can be clinically aggressive due to their tendency to recur. Adamantinomatous (children) and papillary (adults) are two variants of craniopharyngioma. 

Patients usually come to attention due to a headache and visual changes, including decreased acuity or visual field abnormalities (bitemporal hemianopia). These children also have endocrinologic abnormalities such as growth failure and delayed sexual maturation due to pituitary hypofunction and growth hormone deficiency. They are minimally invasive, adhere to the adjacent brain parenchyma, and engulf normal brain structures.

CT may show calcifications within the tumor. MRI shows the presence of solid tumors with cystic components. These tumors appear bright on T1.

They are treated by trans-sphenoidal or trans-cranial resection followed by adjuvant radiation therapy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman slipped while skiing and fell on an outstretched hand. She complains of pain in her right wrist joint and deformity. Her wrist X-rays are shown below. Which muscle do you think exerts tension on the broken distal fragment of the affected bone?
questions.solution:
The brachioradialis inserts into the lowest part of the lateral surface of the radius just above the styloid process. The radius gets fractured 2 cm above its lower end in a Colle’s fracture, and the insertion of the brachioradialis exerts tension.

Colle’s Fracture

The most common fracture among the older generation is a transverse fracture of the distal end of the radius with dorsal displacement of the distal fragment. It is a fracture at the cortico-cancellous junction, and the distal fragment may collapse into extension, dorsal displacement, radial tilt, and shortening.

Management -

  • Undisplaced fracture - immobilisation in a below-elbow plaster cast for six weeks
  • Displaced fractures - manipulative reduction followed by immobilisation in Colles' cast in palmar flexion, pronation, and ulnar deviation.
  • Comminuted fractures -  transfixed percutaneously using two K-wires  

Injuries occurring due to fall on the outstretched hand 

  • Clavicle fracture
  • Anterior dislocation of the shoulder
  • Fracture proximal humerus
  • Fracture shaft of humerus
  • Supracondylar fracture humerus (children)
  • Fracture capitulum
  • Radial head, neck fractures
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Dislocation of elbow
  • Fracture medial epicondyle
  • Monteggia fracture-dislocation
  • Galeazzi fracture-dislocation
  • Colle’s fracture

Fractures around the Wrist Joint

Fracture Description
Monteggia fracture dislocation Fracture shaft of the ulna with dislocation of proximal radio-ulnar joint
Galeazzi fracture-dislocation Fracture distal 1/3rd radius with dislocation/subluxation of distal radio-ulnar joint
Colle’s fracture Fracture distal end of the radius with dorsal displacement of the distal fragment
Smith’s fracture (reverse Colle’s) Fracture distal end of the radius with anterior displacement of the distal fragment
Chauffeurs Fracture Fracture radial styloid
Barton’s Fracture Volar fracture distal radius with volar subluxation of carpus
Scaphoid fracture

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with primary infertility. She has no other complaints. On the hysterosalpingogram, the right fallopian tube has a tobacco pouch appearance. Which part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in this underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario of primary infertility and a hysterosalpingogram finding of the "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube is suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The ampullary part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in genital tuberculosis.     

The fallopian tubes are almost always involved in genital tuberculosis. The lesions are generally bilateral. The mode of spread of the disease is hematogenous, arising from a primary infective focus in the lung. The ampulla is most commonly affected, while the fimbriae and interstitium are spared. 

Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to a primary focus elsewhere. The most frequent location is the lungs (50%), although it can also come from lymph nodes (40%), kidneys, joints, the gastrointestinal system, or as part of a broad miliary infection. It mostly spreads via the haematogenous route or lymphatics sometimes. 

In Genital tuberculosis, the leading presenting complaints include infertility, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well. 

Hysterosalpingogram may reveal the following: 

  • Tobacco pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Lead pipe appearance (rigid, nonperistaltic pipe)
  • Beading and variation due to filling defects
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Jagged fluffiness of tubal outline

Hysteroscopy will reveal the presence of synechiae, partial obliteration of the cavity, the golf-hole appearance of the tubal ostia, and the presence of ulcers.

questions.text: A patient develops a sore throat after general anaesthesia. He was diagnosed as having a postoperative sore throat (POST). The anaesthetist injects a local anaesthetic in the plane of the marked structure. Which of the following pierces the marked structure?

choices.text: Internal laryngeal nerve, accompanied by inferior thyroid vessels
External laryngeal nerve, accompanied by inferior thyroid vessels
Internal laryngeal nerve, accompanied by superior laryngeal vessels
External laryngeal nerve, accompanied by superior laryngeal vessels

questions.solution:
The marked structure shows the thyrohyoid membrane. It is pierced by the internal laryngeal nerve, along with superior laryngeal vessels. USG-guided block of the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is used in the management of POST. 

The diagram given below shows the structures piercing the thyrohyoid membrane.

The thyrohyoid membrane is a fibroblastic layer connecting the superior border of the thyroid cartilage to the superior border of the body and the greater cornu of the hyoid.

It facilitates the ascent of the larynx during swallowing.

It is pierced by superior laryngeal vessels and the internal laryngeal nerve. It, therefore, serves as the potential target for ultrasound-guided local anaesthetic injection if an internal laryngeal block is needed to alleviate POST.

questions.text: A patient presents with cystocele and rectocele. Which level of uterine support is likely to be damaged as per the DeLancey classification?
questions.solution:
Damage to DeLancey level II structures results in cystocele and rectocele.

Level II supports mainly consist of pubocervical fascia anteriorly, rectovaginal fascia (along with septum) posteriorly, and paracolpos (vascular and connective tissue structures present beside the cervix). As the name suggests, pubocervical fascia connects the cervix to the posterior surface of the pubic bone. The rectovaginal septum separates the rectum from the vagina and cervix of the uterus. Together, these structures form a supportive sling that helps maintain the position of the bladder and rectum. Therefore, damage to these structures results in cystocele and rectocele.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

 

Related Pearl: Perineal Body

The perineal body is not a structure but an aggregation of fibromuscular tissue located in the midline at the junction between the anal and urogenital triangles, just ventral to the anal sphincter.

Ten muscles of the perineum converge and interlace in the perineal body.

  • Fibres from External anal sphincter

  • Superficial transverse perenei

Note: In females, sphincter urethrovaginalis is also attached here.

questions.text: While dissecting the inguinal canal, the following structure is noted. Which of the following does not contribute to the coverings of the structure marked as 'A'?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'A' is the spermatic cord. External oblique aponeurosis, internal oblique, and transversalis fascia contribute to the three coverings of the spermatic cord. There is no contribution from the transversus abdominis muscle. 

The coverings of the spermatic cord are:

  1. External spermatic fascia is a continuation of the external oblique aponeurosis and is attached to the superficial inguinal ring. 
  2. Cremasteric fascia and cremasteric muscle are derived from the internal oblique muscle and form the middle covering of the spermatic cord. They are involved in the cremasteric reflex. Gently touching the skin around the anterior aspect of the thigh stimulates the ilioinguinal nerve (afferent). The sensory fibres enter the spinal cord at the L1 level. The efferent nerve is the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2), which causes contraction of the cremasteric muscle and the elevation of the testis. The cremasteric reflex is more active in children and diminishes with age. 
  3. Internal spermatic fascia is derived from transversalis fascia and is attached to the deep inguinal ring. 

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal and spermatic cord contents

Inguinal canal contents:

Male Female
  • Spermatic cord  (with genital branch of genitofemoral nerve)
  • Ilioinguinal nerve
  • Round ligament of the uterus 
  • Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve
  • Ilioinguinal nerve

Spermatic cord contents:

  • Three arteries:
    • Testicular artery
    • Deferential artery
    • Cremasteric artery
  • Two nerves:
    • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve
    • Sympathetic nerve fibers
  • Three other structures:
    • Ductus deferens
    • Pampiniform plexus of veins
    • Lymphatic vessels

questions.text: Identify the structure based on the histological features of the specimen obtained after radical hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.
questions.solution:
The given structure can be identified as a fallopian tube based on the histological features. 

The fallopian tube contains the following structures from the inside out: 

  • Mucous membrane consisting of: 
    • Numerous branching folds mostly fill the entire lumen of the tube. They lie on the basement membrane
    • Peg cells- contain secretory granules
    • Intercalary cells
  • Muscle coat- has two layers of smooth muscles. An inner circular and an outer longitudinal layer of smooth muscle
  • Serosa- contains mesothelium that is supported by the connective tissue

Other options: 

Option A: The ovary consists of the following parts: 

  • Germinal epithelium- it covers the surface of the ovary and is lined by a single layer of cubical cells
  • Tunica albuginea- it is a connective tissue layer on which the germinal layer rests
  • Cortex- it contains a stroma made of reticular fibres and mesenchymal cells. Ovarian follicles at various stages of development are scattered in the stroma
  • Medulla- it contains connective tissue with blood vessels, elastic fibres, and smooth muscle. 

Option B: The cervix is a narrow tube-like structure extending between the uterine cavity and the vagina. Its mucosa consists of numerous obliquely placed palmate folds, glands, and cysts called ovula Nabothi. The mucous membrane of the upper 2/3rd of the canal is lined by ciliated columnar epithelium, over the lower 1/3rd it is lined by non-ciliated columnar epithelium and near the external os, it is lined by stratified squamous epithelium. 

Option D: The vagina consists of the following parts: 

  • Inner mucosa- is lined by stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium. The mucosa is rich in glycogen, and thus, the cells are palely stained.
  • Muscle coat- it is made of outer longitudinal and inner circular fibres
  • Adventitia- it is made of fibrous tissue with many elastic fibres.

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest and widest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient who has been diagnosed with aggressive pancreatic cancer presents with deep abdominal pain in the epigastric region. Intraoperatively, there was retroperitoneal haemorrhage due to erosion of the artery running along the superior border of the pancreas. Which of the following arteries is injured?
questions.solution:
The superior border of the pancreas is formed by the splenic artery which is marked as '4'.

Borders of the pancreas:  

Superior border: Related to the celiac artery and its branches, the common hepatic artery, and the splenic artery.

Inferior border:

  • Behind the gland, the superior mesenteric vessels emerge.
  • The inferior mesenteric vein runs behind the inferior border to join the splenic vein or where the confluence of splenic and superior mesenteric veins meet.

Posterior surface:

  • Devoid of the peritoneum.
  • Anterior to the aorta and the origin of the superior mesenteric artery, left suprarenal gland, the left crus of the diaphragm, left renal vein, and the upper pole of the left kidney surrounded by perirenal fascia 
  • The splenic vein runs on the surface from left to right

Relations of the pancreas 

1) Uncinate process: Anterior - superior mesenteric artery and superior mesenteric vein

2) Neck of the pancreas: Posterior - superior mesenteric vein and portal vein

3) Body of pancreas: Posterior - Splenic vein

4) Tail of pancreas: Present in lienorenal ligament

5) Head of the pancreas: Posterior - inferior vena cava, right and left renal vein

Blood supply of the stomach

The arterial supply of the stomach is contributed exclusively by the celiac trunk through its branches:

  • Left gastric artery - Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
  • Splenic artery
    • Short gastric arteries: Supplies the fundus of the stomach
    • Left gastroepiploic artery: Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach
  • Common hepatic artery
    • Right gastric artery: Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
    • Gastroduodenal artery: The right gastroepiploic artery arises from this and supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a tumor of the mandible is set to undergo mandibular reconstruction. Which of the following is the bone likely to be used for grafting in this patient?
questions.solution:
Vascularised fibular grafts, based on the fibular artery, are the gold standard bone grafts preferred in mandibular reconstruction procedures.

Since fibula does not take part in the transmission of body weight, it is a common source of bone for grafting.

The fibular artery has five perforators. While the fibular graft based on the fibular artery is used for mandibular reconstruction, small fasciocutaneous and adipofascial flaps based on the perforators can be used for covering soft tissue defects. Therefore, this graft provides convenient tissue for the simultaneous reconstruction of bony and soft tissue defects inside as well as outside the oral cavity.

questions.text: A patient who underwent parotidectomy developed sweating that occurs when he smells or tastes food. It was suspected to be due to aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic fibres to the parotid gland. Which of the following foramina do these fibres pass through?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of sweating occurring while smelling or tasting food, secondary to aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic fibres, suggests Frey's syndrome. These fibres to the parotid gland pass through the foramen ovale and jugular foramen, marked as 2 and 4 in the image, respectively.

Parasympathetic nerves are secretomotor to the parotid gland. The preganglionic parasympathetic fibres begin in the inferior salivatory nucleus. These fibres travel via the glossopharyngeal nerve and reach the tympanic plexus via the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve through the jugular foramen. Then, these fibres travel via the lesser petrosal nerve and come out of the foramen ovale to relay in the otic ganglion. The postganglionic parasympathetic fibres emerging from the otic ganglion pass via the auriculotemporal nerve to reach the parotid gland.

The image given below shows the parasympathetic pathway of the parotid gland.

Frey's syndrome occurs due to aberrant regeneration of the parasympathetic nerve fibres of the auriculotemporal nerve. This results in abnormal innervation of sweat glands on the face. Patients usually present with sweating, warmth, and redness of the face when they smell or taste food. 

The sympathetic supply to the parotid gland is derived from the plexus around the middle meningeal artery.

Sensory supply to the parotid gland is from the auriculotemporal nerve, and the parotid capsule is from the sensory fibres of the greater auricular nerve.

Foraminas marked in the image are:

  1. Foramen rotundum
  2. Foramen ovale
  3. Foramen spinosum
  4. Jugular foramen

    • Apical ligament and tip of dens
    • Upper band of cruciate ligament
    • Membrana tectoria
  • Neuro-vascular (posterior) compartment:
    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges
    • Fourth part of vertebral artery surrounded by sympathetic plexus of nerves
    • Spinal roots of accessory nerves
    • Anterior and posterior spinal arteries
    • Tonsil of cerebellum.

questions.text: A male patient was diagnosed with an aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery. He has ocular symptoms suggestive of third cranial nerve palsy. Which of the muscles marked in the given image is not supplied by this nerve?
questions.solution:
The muscle marked as '3' in the image is superior oblique, which is innervated by the trochlear nerve (4th cranial nerve). The other muscles marked in the image, i.e., 1- superior rectus, 2- levator palpebrae superioris, and 4- inferior oblique, are supplied by the oculomotor nerve (3rd cranial nerve).

Muscles present around the eye:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

Levator palpebrae superioris originates from the lesser wing of the sphenoid, anterior to the optic canal. It inserts into the tarsal plate, superior conjunctival fornix, and skin. 

The four recti muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera in the anterior half of the eyeball.

The superior oblique originates from the body of the sphenoid, superior and medial to optic canal. The inferior oblique originates from the medial floor of the orbit and maxilla. They are inserted into the sclera of the outer posterior quadrant of the eyeball in the superior surface and inferior surface, respectively.

All the extraocular muscles (including the inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus, which is innervated by the abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique, which is innervated by the trochlear (IV) nerve

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: A boy came to the hospital with complaints of diplopia and progressive headache. Examination of extraocular movements revealed the findings as shown in the image when the patient attempted to look right. At what level of the brainstem does the affected cranial nerve nucleus arise?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding shown in the image is suggestive of lateral rectus palsy of the right eye. This occurs due to the lesion involving the abducens nerve. The abducens nerve nucleus arises at the level of facial colliculus in the pons. 

Facial colliculus is present at the floor of the fourth ventricle at the level of the lower pontine tegmentum. This colliculus contains the abducens nerve nucleus and the fibers of the internal genu of the facial nerve which travels around the abducens nerve nucleus as shown in the image above. The abducens nerve then emerges out of the brainstem between the pons and the medulla and runs through the Dorello's canal. The abducens nerve then enters the superior orbital fissure via the cavernous sinus and innervates the lateral rectus muscle.

Determining the palsy:

The abduction and adduction of the eye are caused by the action of the lateral rectus and medial rectus muscles respectively. The lateral rectus is innervated by the abducens nerve (VI) while the medial rectus is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (III).

Horizontal conjugate movements occur when both eyes move horizontally to look right or left.

  • In right gaze: The right eye abducts and the left eye adducts.
  • In left gaze: The right eye adducts and the left eye abducts.

In the image, when the patient attempted to look right, the left eye adducted normally, while the right eye failed to abduct. This is suggestive of right lateral rectus palsy due to the lesion involving the right abducens nerve.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is looking straight (neutral gaze), then the affected eye is the left eye. In such a case, due to left lateral rectus palsy, the action of the left medial rectus is unopposed causing adduction of the left eye.

Other options:

Option A: The superior colliculus lies in the upper midbrain. At this level, the oculomotor nerve nucleus is present and the nerve emerges out of the midbrain.

Option B: Inferior colliculus lies in the lower midbrain. At this level, the trochlear nerve nucleus is present.

Option D: The inferior olivary nucleus is present in the superior half of the medulla. At this level, the hypoglossal nerve is present.

Related Pearl: Origins of cranial nerves at the base of the brain

Cranial nerve origins as seen in gross anatomy:

  • III cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of the superior colliculus.  
  • IV cranial nerve: Midbrain at the level of inferior colliculus - the only nerve the exits from the dorsal aspect
  • V cranial nerve: The substance of pons 
  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient has been brought to the hospital following blunt trauma to the chest and abdomen. On examination, it was found that the structures passing through the most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening situated at the level of the T12 vertebra have been injured. All of the following structures are injured in this case except?
questions.solution:
The most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening situated at the level of the T12 vertebra is the aortic opening. The right vagus nerve is not injured in the given case as it passes through the oesophageal opening while all these other structures are injured.

The diaphragm has several openings through which structures can pass between the thorax and abdomen. There are three large openings and several smaller openings. The large openings are the aortic hiatus, the oesophagal hiatus, and the caval hiatus.

The aortic opening is the most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening. It is found at the level of the lower border of the twelfth thoracic vertebra and the corresponding intervertebral disc. It is bounded by the diaphragmatic crura laterally, the vertebral column posteriorly, and the median arcuate ligament anteriorly. 

Structures passing through the aortic opening are,

  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Azygous vein
  • Hemiazygous vein

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with a mass at the anus associated with painless bleeding. Examination revealed the following findings. Identify the correct pair of involved veins and their tributaries in this condition.

choices.text: Inferior rectal vein→ Inferior mesenteric vein
Superior rectal vein→ Inferior mesenteric vein
Middle rectal vein→ Inferior mesenteric vein

questions.solution:
The given scenario and image are suggestive of internal haemorrhoids. The correctly involved veins and tributaries are superior rectal veins draining into the inferior mesenteric vein. In the image, the mass is appearing to arise above the level of the dentate line, and prominent enlargement can be found at the 3 o’clock, 11 o’clock, and 7 o’clock positions.

Internal haemorrhoids arise from the hemorrhoidal plexus consisting of 3 soft engorgements, referred to as anal cushions or haemorrhoids. Upright posture, the absence of valves in the portal venous system, and raised abdominal pressure contribute to venous plexus engorgement and the development of varicosities. 

Patients will present with painless bleeding per rectum and mass near the anal orifice.

The venous plexus and its drainage are as follows:

The upper part of the anal canal, including the internal hemorrhoidal plexus:

  • The superior rectal vein draining into the inferior mesenteric vein- Portal vein tributaries
  • The middle rectal vein draining into the internal iliac vein- Systemic veins

The lower part of the anal canal, including the external haemorrhoidal venous plexus:

  • The inferior rectal veins into the internal pudendal veins (later into the internal iliac vein)- Systemic veins

The rectal venous plexus is, therefore, a site of communication between the portal and systemic venous systems. Hence, patients with portal hypertension develop rectal varices that should not be confused with haemorrhoids.

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Internal hemorrhoids External hemorrhoids
Located proximal to the dentate line

Located distal to the dentate line
Covered by transitional and columnar epithelium Covered by richly innervated squamous epithelium
Caused by pressure on superior rectal veins Caused by pressure on inferior rectal veins
Painless, can be ligated Painful, not ligated
Banding is preferred Excision is done
